README.html.title: cshrix-bot
README.html.keywords: cshrix-bot Master Develop Matrix bot using the cshrix library. This bot is a work in progress, when it is more finalized, the core library to interact with Matrix will be extracted into its own repository. Acknowledgements Big thanks to the almighty @expectocode for coming up with a name for this project. License Copyright Â© 2019 by Adam Hellberg . This Source Code Form is subject to the terms of the Mozilla Public License, v. 2.0 . If a copy of the MPL was not distributed with this file, You can obtain one at http://mozilla.org/MPL/2.0/ . See the file LICENSE for more details. Code of Conduct This project is covered under a Code of Conduct , please remember to adhere by this when interacting with the project. Contributing Please see the CONTRIBUTING document for our contribution guidelines. End-to-end (E2E) encryption In order for E2EE features to work, libolm must be available on the system PATH or located alongside the executable (cshrix calls into it using P/Interop). Linux Check if your distro's package manager has libolm available. It usually goes under the name libolm and/or libolm-dev . Debian/Ubuntu Debian: buster/sid and later. Ubuntu: 18.04 (bionic) and later. # apt install libolm-dev Arch libolm is available in the AUR and as a git version . Windows As of right now (2019-04-23), no official Windows releases of libolm exist. Build the library manually and place it either somewhere on the PATH or alongside the executable. macOS Unknown. If someone has information about libolm on macOS, please make a PR and update this section.

CODE_OF_CONDUCT.html.title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
CODE_OF_CONDUCT.html.keywords: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct Our Pledge In the interest of fostering an open and welcoming environment, we as contributors and maintainers pledge to making participation in our project and our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation. Our Standards Examples of behavior that contributes to creating a positive environment include: Using welcoming and inclusive language Being respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences Gracefully accepting constructive criticism Focusing on what is best for the community Showing empathy towards other community members Examples of unacceptable behavior by participants include: The use of sexualized language or imagery and unwelcome sexual attention or advances Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks Public or private harassment Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or electronic address, without explicit permission Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting Our Responsibilities Project maintainers are responsible for clarifying the standards of acceptable behavior and are expected to take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any instances of unacceptable behavior. Project maintainers have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, or to ban temporarily or permanently any contributor for other behaviors that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful. Scope This Code of Conduct applies both within project spaces and in public spaces when an individual is representing the project or its community. Examples of representing a project or community include using an official project e-mail address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed representative at an online or offline event. Representation of a project may be further defined and clarified by project maintainers. Enforcement Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported by contacting the project team at matrix@sharparam.com. All complaints will be reviewed and investigated and will result in a response that is deemed necessary and appropriate to the circumstances. The project team is obligated to maintain confidentiality with regard to the reporter of an incident. Further details of specific enforcement policies may be posted separately. Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good faith may face temporary or permanent repercussions as determined by other members of the project's leadership. Attribution This Code of Conduct is adapted from the Contributor Covenant , version 1.4, available at https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/1/4/code-of-conduct.html For answers to common questions about this code of conduct, see https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq

CONTRIBUTING.html.title: Contributing guidelines
CONTRIBUTING.html.keywords: Contributing guidelines Thank you for your interest in contributing to cshrix-bot ! This document describes guidelines you need to follow when developing code for or otherwise contributing to this project. Please read through this document in its entirety before contributing. If you have any questions, do not hesitate to contact me or open an issue in this repository with your question. You can also join #cshrix-bot:matrix.sharparam.com on Matrix to discuss potential changes. Code of Conduct This repository is covered by a Code of Conduct . If you notice anyone breaking the CoC or have questions about it, please contact @Sharparam or send an email to matrix@sharparam.com . Reporting issues or requesting features If you want to report an issue, bug, or request a new feature to be added, please open a new issue and describe your bug or feature request. There are different issue templates defined depending on what you are reporting. We kindly ask that you do not "fire and forget" issues. If you report an issue then please remember to come back and respond to any questions or feedback given by us! Code style This project defines a code style compatible with both ReSharper and Rider, please make use of them if you are in a supported environment. The project also has an EditorConfig file supplied, defining some basic formatting rules. Below follow some basic style guidelines but they may not be exhaustive due to the immense number of rules defined in the settings. For a definitive list of what style rules are required, consult the EditorConfig and solution settings files. File header Each file should begin with the following header text: Copyright (c) 2019 by Adam Hellberg. This Source Code Form is subject to the terms of the Mozilla Public License, v. 2.0. If a copy of the MPL was not distributed with this file, You can obtain one at http://mozilla.org/MPL/2.0/. Additionally, for C# source code files, wrap the notice inside a copyright tag: // <copyright file="MyFile.cs"> // Copyright (c) 2019 by Adam Hellberg. // // This Source Code Form is subject to the terms of the Mozilla Public // License, v. 2.0. If a copy of the MPL was not distributed with this // file, You can obtain one at http://mozilla.org/MPL/2.0/. // </copyright> The ReSharper/Rider settings include a file template which inserts this text automatically in new files created by them. Indentation Indentation is done only with space, unless tabs are required by the file format. The number of spaces to indent with is by default 4, but can be different in certain file types, as shown below. Indentation of C# source files is done with 4 spaces. Indentation of XML files (including CSPROJ files) is done with 2 spaces. Indentation of YAML and JSON files is done with 2 spaces. For other files, consult the EditorConfig files. EOL whitespace All end-of-line (EOL) whitespace is to be stripped from all files. If a file format explicitly requires EOL whitespace for some functionality, exceptions can be made and will be listed in the EditorConfig file. Naming rules Private non-readonly fields: _lowerCamelCase Parameters: lowerCamelCase Local variables: lowerCamelCase Interfaces: IUpperCamelCase Type parameters: TUpperCamelCase Everything else: UpperCamelCase (AKA PascalCase ) The above naming rules are defined in the ReSharper/Rider settings. In addition, async methods must be namd with an Async suffix. For example: async Task DoSomethingAsync() . Names of type parameters should either be a singular T , or a T followed by a PascalCased name, like TError . Braces Brace layout is to put braces on the next line for all constructs that use braces, for example: namespace Test { public class Foo { } } For short inline stuff like arrays, braces on one line can be accepted, for example: var mySimpleArray = new int[] { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 }; File layout Follow the same file layout as mandated by StyleCop ( SA1201 and SA1203 ). Using statements using statements are placed as deep as possible, usually this means placing them just inside the namespace definition. They should also be alphabetically ordered and grouped based on the top-level name, with the exception that the System namespace is always the first group. Fully qualified using statements are not required when they can be shortened. For example: namespace Test { using System; using System.Net; using Cshrix; using Newtonsoft.Json; public class Foo { } } Miscellaneous Use var where possible.

api/Cshrix.Data.HistoryVisibility.html.title: Enum HistoryVisibility
api/Cshrix.Data.HistoryVisibility.html.keywords: Enum HistoryVisibility Different history visibility states for a room. Namespace : Cshrix.Data Assembly : Cshrix.dll Syntax [JsonConverter(typeof(StringEnumConverter))] public enum HistoryVisibility Fields Name Description Invited History is available to joined users from the point in time they were invited. Joined History is available to joined users from the point in time they joined. Shared All history is available to joined users. WorldReadable Anyone can read history, even non-joined users.

Inheritance Object Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter < NotificationAction > NotificationActionConverter Inherited Members Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter<Cshrix.Data.Notifications.NotificationAction>.WriteJson(Newtonsoft.Json.JsonWriter, System.Object, Newtonsoft.Json.JsonSerializer) Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter<Cshrix.Data.Notifications.NotificationAction>.ReadJson(Newtonsoft.Json.JsonReader, System.Type, System.Object, Newtonsoft.Json.JsonSerializer) Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter<Cshrix.Data.Notifications.NotificationAction>.CanConvert(System.Type) Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter.CanRead Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter.CanWrite Object.Equals(Object) Object.Equals(Object, Object) Object.GetHashCode() Object.GetType() Object.MemberwiseClone() Object.ReferenceEquals(Object, Object) Object.ToString() Namespace : Cshrix.Serialization Assembly : Cshrix.dll Syntax public class NotificationActionConverter : JsonConverter<NotificationAction> Remarks The Matrix API can send/receive notification actions either as a string (for simple actions), or as an object specifying additional parameters. This custom serializer makes it possible to represent both as complete objects on the C# side, while the API can send and receive what it expects. Methods | Improve this Doc View Source ReadJson(JsonReader, Type, NotificationAction, Boolean, JsonSerializer) Reads the JSON representation of a NotificationAction . Declaration public override NotificationAction ReadJson(JsonReader reader, Type objectType, NotificationAction existingValue, bool hasExistingValue, JsonSerializer serializer) Parameters Type Name Description Newtonsoft.Json.JsonReader reader The Newtonsoft.Json.JsonReader to read from. Type objectType Type of the object. NotificationAction existingValue The existing value of object being read. If there is no existing value then null will be used. Boolean hasExistingValue The existing value has a value. Newtonsoft.Json.JsonSerializer serializer The calling serializer. Returns Type Description NotificationAction The NotificationAction value. Overrides Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter<Cshrix.Data.Notifications.NotificationAction>.ReadJson(Newtonsoft.Json.JsonReader, System.Type, Cshrix.Data.Notifications.NotificationAction, System.Boolean, Newtonsoft.Json.JsonSerializer) Remarks If the JSON value is a simple string, it gets deserialized into a NotificationAction with only Action set. If, on the other hand, the JSON value is an object, the deserializer will attempt to extract relevant values from it, as specified by the API. Examples var json = "\"notify\""; var action = JsonConvert.DeserializeObject<NotificationAction>(json); // action has its Action property set to "notify" var json = "{ \"set_tweak\": \"highlight\", \"value\": false }"; var action = JsonConvert.DeserializeObject<NotificationAction>(json); // action has the following properties: // Action = "set_tweak" // Name = "highlight" // Value = false | Improve this Doc View Source WriteJson(JsonWriter, NotificationAction, JsonSerializer) Writes the JSON representation of an instance of NotificationAction . Declaration public override void WriteJson(JsonWriter writer, NotificationAction value, JsonSerializer serializer) Parameters Type Name Description Newtonsoft.Json.JsonWriter writer The Newtonsoft.Json.JsonWriter to write to. NotificationAction value The value. Newtonsoft.Json.JsonSerializer serializer The calling serializer. Overrides Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConverter<Cshrix.Data.Notifications.NotificationAction>.WriteJson(Newtonsoft.Json.JsonWriter, Cshrix.Data.Notifications.NotificationAction, Newtonsoft.Json.JsonSerializer) Remarks If value only has Action specified, then the serializer will product a simple string value, as expected by the API. If, on the other hand, the value has one or both of Name and/or Value specified, then it will serialize into a complete object representation, with set_tweak set to the value of Name . Examples var action = new NotificationAction("notify"); var json = JsonConvert.SerializeObject(action); // Value of json: "notify" var action = new NotificationAction("set_tweak", "highlight", true); var json = JsonConvert.SerializeObject(action); // Value of json: { "set_tweak": "highlight", "value": true }

Declaration [Post("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/rooms/{roomId}/ban")] Task BanAsync([Path] string roomId, [Body] Reason data) Parameters Type Name Description String roomId The ID of the room from which the user should be banned. Reason data An object that contains the user ID that should be banned, along with a reason. Returns Type Description Task A Task representing request progress. Remarks Ban a user in the room. If the user is currently in the room, also kick them. When a user is banned from a room, they may not join it or be invited to it until they are unbanned. The caller must have the required power level in order to perform this operation. | Improve this Doc View Source ChangePasswordAsync(ChangePasswordRequest) Changes a user's password. Declaration [Post("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/account/password")] Task<HttpResponseMessage> ChangePasswordAsync([Body] ChangePasswordRequest data) Parameters Type Name Description ChangePasswordRequest data Password and authentication data. Returns Type Description Task < HttpResponseMessage > A HttpResponseMessage with details on the API response. Remarks Changes the password for an account on the homeserver. This API endpoint uses the User-Interactive Authentication API . An access token should be submitted to this endpoint if the client has an active session. The homeserver may change the flows available depending on whether a valid access token is provided. Due to the interactive nature of this endpoint, the returned HttpResponseMessage must be inspected for 401 status and a returned UnauthorizedError error. This can be more easily done by using the extension methods defined in HttpResponseMessageExtensions . | Improve this Doc View Source ClaimOneTimeKeysAsync(ClaimKeysRequest) Claim one-time encryption keys (OTKs). Declaration [Post("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/keys/claim")] Task<ClaimKeysResponse> ClaimOneTimeKeysAsync([Body] ClaimKeysRequest data) Parameters Type Name Description ClaimKeysRequest data Data specifying keys to request. Returns Type Description Task < ClaimKeysResponse > The claimed keys. Remarks Claims one-time keys (OTKs) for use in pre-key messages. | Improve this Doc View Source CreateRoomAsync(CreateRoomRequest) Create a new room. Declaration [Post("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/createRoom")] Task<RoomIdContainer> CreateRoomAsync([Body] CreateRoomRequest data) Parameters Type Name Description CreateRoomRequest data The desired room configuration. Returns Type Description Task < RoomIdContainer > A wrapper object containing the ID of the created room. Remarks Creates a new room with various configuration options. The server must apply the normal state resolution rules when creating the new room, including checking power levels for each event. It must apply the events implied by the request in the following order: A default m.room.power_levels event, giving the room creator (and not other members) permission to send state events. Overridden by the PowerLevelsOverride parameter. Events set by the Preset . Currently these are the m.room.join_rules , m.room.history_visibility , and m.room.guest_access state events. Events listed in InitialState , in the order that they are listed. Events implied by Name and Topic ( m.room.name and m.room.topic state events). Invite events implied by Invites and ThirdPartyInvites ( m.room.member with Invited and m.room.third_party_invite ). The available presets do the following with respect to room state: Preset JoinRule HistoryVisibility GuestAccess Other PrivateChat Invite Shared CanJoin TrustedPrivateChat Invite Shared CanJoin All invitees are given the same power level as the room creator. PublicChat Public Shared CanJoin The server will create a m.room.create event in the room with the requesting user as the creator, alongside other keys provided in Content . | Improve this Doc View Source DeactivateAccountAsync(AuthenticationContainer) Deactivates a user's account. Declaration [Post("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/account/deactivate")] Task<HttpResponseMessage> DeactivateAccountAsync([Body] AuthenticationContainer data) Parameters Type Name Description AuthenticationContainer data Authentication data. Returns Type Description Task < HttpResponseMessage > A HttpResponseMessage with details on the API response. Remarks Deactivates the user's account, removing all ability for the user to login again. This API endpoint uses the User-Interactive Authentication API . An access token should be submitted to this endpoint if the client has an active session. The homeserver may change the flows available depending on whether a valid access token is provided. Due to the interactive nature of this endpoint, the returned HttpResponseMessage must be inspected for 401 status and a returned UnauthorizedError error. This can be more easily done by using the extension methods defined in HttpResponseMessageExtensions . | Improve this Doc View Source DeleteDeviceAsync(String, AuthenticationContainer) Delete a device. Declaration [Get("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/keys/changes")] Task<DeviceChangeLists> GetDeviceKeyChangesAsync([Query] string from, [Query] string to) Parameters Type Name Description String from The desired start point of the list. Should be the next_batch field from a response to an earlier call to SyncAsync(String, String, Boolean, Presence, TimeSpan, CancellationToken) . Users who have not uploaded new device identity keys since this point, nor deleted existing devices with identity keys since then, will be excluded from the results. String to The desired end point of the list. Should be the next_batch field from a recent call to SyncAsync(String, String, Boolean, Presence, TimeSpan, CancellationToken) - typically the most recent such call. This may be used by the server as a hint to check its caches are up to date. Returns Type Description Task < DeviceChangeLists > Lists of users who have had device changes. Remarks Gets lists of users who have updated their device identity keys since a previous sync token. The server should include in the results any users who: Currently share a room with the calling user (i.e. both users have membership state Joined ); and Added new device identity keys or removed an existing device with identity keys, between from and to . | Improve this Doc View Source GetDevicesAsync() List registered devices for the current user. Declaration [Post("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/rooms/{roomId}/invite")] Task InviteAsync([Path] string roomId, [Body] ThirdPartyRoomInvite data) Parameters Type Name Description String roomId The ID of the room to which to invite the user. ThirdPartyRoomInvite data An object containing information about the 3PID to use for sending the invite. Returns Type Description Task A Task representing request progress. Remarks Note that there are two forms of this API, which are documented separately. This version of the API does not require that the inviter know the Matrix identifier of the invitee, and instead relies on third party identifiers. The homeserver uses an identity server to perform the mapping from third party identifier to a Matrix identifier. The other is documented here: InviteAsync(String, UserIdContainer) . This API invites a user to participate in a particular room. They do not start participating in the room until they actually join the room. Only users currently in a particular room can invite other users to join that room. If the identity server did know the Matrix user identifier for the third party identifier, the homeserver will append a m.room.member event to the room. If the identity server does not know a Matrix user identifier for the passed third party identifier, the homeserver will issue an invitation which can be accepted upon providing proof of ownership of the third party identifier. This is achieved by the identity server generating a token, which it gives to the inviting homeserver. The homeserver will add an m.room.third_party_invite event into the graph for the room, containing that token. When the invitee binds the invited third party identifier to a Matrix user ID, the identity server will give the user a list of pending invitations, each containing: The room ID to which they were invited. The token given to the homeserver. A signature of the token, signed with the identity server's private key. The Matrix user ID who invited them to the room. If a token is requested from the identity server, the homeserver will append a m.room.third_party_invite event to the room. | Improve this Doc View Source InviteAsync(String, UserIdContainer) Invite a user to participate in a particular room. Declaration [Get("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/register/available")] Task<Response<AvailableContainer>> IsRegistrationAvailableAsync([Query] string username) Parameters Type Name Description String username The username to check the availability of. Returns Type Description Task < RestEase.Response < AvailableContainer >> The RestEase.Response<T> from the API, containing an AvailableContainer on success. If the request failed, the response should be inspected for a MatrixError explaining in more detail why it failed or why the username was not available. The Matrix developers, in their infinite wisdom, has created yet another useless wrapper object for this API, so the AvailableContainer never has to actually be inspected on a successful API call, as it will always be true . Remarks Checks to see if a username is available, and valid, for the server. The server should check to ensure that, at the time of the request, the username requested is available for use. This includes verifying that an application service has not claimed the username and that the username fits the server's desired requirements (for example, a server could dictate that it does not permit usernames with underscores). Matrix clients may wish to use this API prior to attempting registration, however the clients must also be aware that using this API does not normally reserve the username. This can mean that the username becomes unavailable between checking its availability and attempting to register it. | Improve this Doc View Source JoinRoomAsync(String, Nullable<SignedThirdPartyData>) Start the requesting user participating in a particular room. Declaration [Post("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/logout/all")] Task LogoutAllAsync() Returns Type Description Task A Task representing request progress. Remarks Invalidates all access tokens for a user, so that they can no longer be used for authorization. This includes the access token that made this request. This endpoint does not require UI authorization because UI authorization is designed to protect against attacks where someone gets hold of a single access token and then takes over the account. Declaration [Post("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/register")] Task<Response<AuthenticationResponse>> RegisterAsync([Body] RegistrationRequest data) Parameters Type Name Description RegistrationRequest data Registration data. Returns Type Description Task < RestEase.Response < AuthenticationResponse >> A RestEase.Response<T> object containing an AuthenticationResponse for the registered user, on success. On failure, inspect the returned response for an UnauthorizedError for details on what flows to use for authentication. Remarks This API endpoint uses the User-Interactive Authentication API . Register for an account on this homeserver. There are two kinds of user account: user accounts. These accounts may use the full API described in this specification. guest accounts. These accounts may have limited permissions and may not be supported by all servers. If registration is successful, this endpoint will issue an access token the client can use to authorize itself in subsequent requests. If the client does not supply a DeviceId , the server must auto-generate one. The server should register an account with a user ID based on the Username provided, if any. Note that the grammar of Matrix user ID localparts is restricted, so the server must either map the provided Username onto a UserId in a logical manner, or reject usernames which do not comply to the grammar, with M_INVALID_USERNAME . Matrix clients must not assume that Localpart of the registered UserId matches the provided Username . The returned access token must be associated with the DeviceId supplied by the client or generated by the server. The server may invalidate any access token previously associated with that device. Declaration [Get("_matrix/client/{apiVersion}/sync")] Task<SyncResponse> SyncAsync([Query] string since = null, [Query] string filter = null, [Query("full_state", QuerySerializationMethod.Serialized)] bool fullState = false, [Query("set_presence", QuerySerializationMethod.Serialized)] Presence presence = Presence.Online, [Query(QuerySerializationMethod.Serialized)] TimeSpan timeout = default(TimeSpan), CancellationToken cancellationToken = default(CancellationToken)) Parameters Type Name Description String since A point in time to continue sync from. String filter The ID of a filter created using the filter API or a filter JSON object encoded as a string. The server will detect whether it is an ID or a JSON object by whether the first character is a { open brace. Passing the JSON inline is best suited to one-off requests. Creating a filter using the filter API is recommended for clients that reuse the same filter multiple times, for example in long poll requests. Boolean fullState Controls whether to include the full state for all rooms the user is a member of. If this is set to true , then all state events will be returned, even if since is non-empty. The timeline will still be limited by the since parameter. In this case, the timeout parameter will be ignored and the query will return immediately, possibly with an empty timeline. If false , and since is non-empty, only state which has changed since the point indicated by since will be returned. Presence presence Controls whether the client is automatically marked as online by polling this API. If this parameter is omitted then the client is automatically marked as online when it uses this API. Otherwise if the parameter is set to Offline then the client is not marked as being online when it uses this API. When set to Unavailable , the client is marked as being idle. TimeSpan timeout The maximum time to wait before returning this request. If no events (or other data) become available before this time elapses, the server will return a response with empty fields. By default, this is Zero , so the server will return immediately even if the response is empty. CancellationToken cancellationToken Cancellation token to pass to the underlying HTTP requester. Returns Type Description Task < SyncResponse > The initial snapshot or delta for the client to use to update their state. Remarks Synchronise the client's state with the latest state on the server. Clients use this API when they first log in to get an initial snapshot of the state on the server, and then continue to call this API to get incremental deltas to the state, and to receive new events. | Improve this Doc View Source UnbanAsync(String, UserIdContainer) Unban a user from the room. The caller must have the required power level in order to perform this operation. | Improve this Doc View Source UpdateAppServiceRoomVisibilityAsync(String, String, RoomVisibilityContainer) Updates a room's visibility in the application service's room directory. api/Cshrix.Data.Authentication.html.title: Namespace Cshrix.Data.Authentication
api/Cshrix.Data.Authentication.html.keywords: Namespace Cshrix.Data.Authentication Classes AuthenticationContainer Contains authentication data for the User-Interactive Authentication API . AuthenticationData Contains authentication data. DummyAuthentication Dummy authentication data. EmailAuthentication Authentication is supported by authorising an email address with an identity server. PasswordAuthentication An authentication method where the client submits an identifier and secret password, both sent in plain-text. ReCaptchaAuthentication The user completes a Google ReCaptcha 2.0 challenge. TokenAuthentication The client submits a login token. Structs AuthenticationFlow Defines an authentication flow for a homeserver. AuthenticationResponse A response returned on successful authentication. LoginFlow Describes a login flow. LoginFlows Contains supported login flows on the homeserver. LoginRequest Describes a request to login to a homeserver. Enums AuthenticationType Available authentication types.

api/Cshrix.Data.html.title: Namespace Cshrix.Data
api/Cshrix.Data.html.keywords: Namespace Cshrix.Data Classes Chunk<T> A chunk of data. EventFilter Describes a filter for events. GroupId Represents the ID of a group on Matrix. Identifier Represents an abstract identifier. InvitedEventArgs Contains the data for the event when the user is invited to a room. PaginatedChunk<T> A paginated chunk of data. PublicRoomsChunk Contains a list of public rooms on a server, along with pagination data. RoomAlias Represents an alias for a room. RoomEventFilter Specifies a filter for room events in search APIs. SessionContainer Contains additional data for the User-Interactive Authentication API . SignedData Contains content that has been signed, which can be used to verify an event. SignedSenderData Contains signed data. Like SignedData but additionally has a sender ID. SyncEventArgs Contains the sync response on a sync event. UserId The MXID of a user on Matrix. Structs AvailableContainer Contains a boolean value indicating whether a resource or action is available. AvatarUriContainer An object containing an avatar URI. BaseUriContainer Gets an object containing a base URI. ChangePasswordRequest Describes a password change request. ClientInfo Contains information about what servers a client should use for communicating with a homeserver. ConnectionInfo Contains information about a connection. Content Contains content downloaded from a Matrix media repository. ContentConfiguration Contains homeserver content configuration. ContentUriContainer A wrapper object that contains a content URI. CreateRoomRequest Specifies the data used for creating a new room. DisplayNameContainer An object containing a display name. EnabledContainer A wrapper containing a value indicating whether something is enabled or not. EventContext Contains details about an event and its context. EventIdContainer An object containing an event ID. Filter Describes a filter for events. FilterIdContainer An object containing a filter ID. JoinedMembersResponse Contains information about users joined to a room. JoinedRooms Contains a collection of room IDs that a user has joined. LocalpartUserIdentifier Identifies a user by their localpart. OpenIdToken An OpenID token. PhoneUserIdentifier Identifies a user by their phone number. PreviewInfo Preview information about a URI. Any of the properties may be null or otherwise not present. Profile Contains profile information for a user. PublicRoom Contains data on a public room. PublicRoomsFilter Contains information on how to filter a request to list public rooms. PublicRoomsRequest Specifies filters when retrieving public rooms from a server. ReadMarkers Specifies which event IDs the read marker and receipt should be set at. Reason Contains a reason for a kick or ban. RegistrationRequest Contains information required to request user registration. Report Contains information about a message report. RoomAliasInformation Contains information about a room alias. RoomFilter Contains a filter to be applied to room data. RoomIdContainer An object containing a room ID. RoomVisibilityContainer An object containing a room visibility value. SendToDeviceMessages Contains messages to send to specified client devices. ServerName Represents a homeserver domain. SessionInfo Contains information about a session. SignedSenderDataContainer A wrapper for SignedData . TagData Contains data for a tag. TagsResponse Contains tags for a room. ThirdPartyUserIdentifier Identifies a user by one of their third party identifier. TurnServerCredentials Credentials for a TURN server(s). UnsignedDeviceInfo Additional data added to device key information that is not covered by signatures. UserIdContainer A wrapper containing a UserId . UserIdUserIdentifier Identifies a user by their full Matrix user ID. VersionsResponse Contains the list of versions supported by the server. WhoisResponse Contains the result of a whois request. Its purpose is to allow servers to not require any form of User-Interactive Authentication to perform a request. Email Authentication is supported by authorising an email address with an identity server. Oauth2 Authentication is supported via OAuth2 URLs. This login consists of multiple requests. Password The client submits an identifier and secret password, both sent in plain-text. ReCaptcha The user completes a Google ReCaptcha 2.0 challenge. Token The client submits a login token.
